terms.definition: Software as a Service - a cloud-based software delivery model where applications are hosted by a provider and accessed via the internet
A centralized repository of information, documentation, and resources that provides answers to common questions and solutions to problems
A system that tracks and manages changes to documents or code over time, allowing users to see revision history and revert to previous versions
Standard Operating Procedures - detailed written instructions that describe how to perform routine tasks or processes consistently and safely
Software or services that are hosted on remote servers and accessed via the internet rather than installed locally on individual computers
Isolated collections of data that are stored separately and cannot be easily accessed or shared across different systems or departments
Enterprise Resource Planning - integrated software systems that manage and automate core business processes across an organization
The ability of software to display content and interface elements in multiple languages for international users
Pre-designed document formats or structures that provide a standardized starting point for creating consistent documentation
The ability to instantly synchronize and display changes to documents or data as they occur, without manual refresh or delay
A single, unified location where all documents, files, or data are stored and managed, providing a single source of truth
The process of connecting different software systems or platforms so they can share data and work together seamlessly
Software features that enable multiple users to work together on documents simultaneously, including commenting, editing, and review capabilities
An interconnected network of digital tools, platforms, and systems that work together to support business operations and workflows
Formal documents that demonstrate adherence to regulatory requirements, industry standards, or internal policies through documented evidence
